title: Bush Turnpike right-of-way clearance
text: The section between I-30 and West Main (Highway 180) required a large clearance through a residential area. Several commercial properties near I-30 were also displaced. The clearance was nearly complete at the time these photos were taken in 2004.

images.caption: This map shows the area where the major right-of-way clearance took place. However, the area shown in these photos was not the neighborhood which filed the lawsuit against the project. The neighborhood filing the lawsuit was on the northwest side of the I-30/Bush Turnpike interchange. The 1983 lawsuit resulted in a 1985 court injunction which prevented further work. The injunction was lifted in 1998, and an appeals court ended legal action in 2000 by ruling in favor of the freeway.
Cleared right-of-way north of Main Street. Only one structure remained, visible in the distance
A closer view of the remaining structure.
This home was prepared for transport.
This slab remained along Dalworth street.
Looking north along 14th Street, with the cleared area on the left.
Home being cleared near 14th and Cain.
Most of the houses on this street (probably Cain street) are cleared.
Only slabs remain.
Church about the be demolished.
Three months later the church was reduced to its main structural components.
The church interior
Home near the church being demolished.
This structure along 19th Street was vacated, awaiting demolition.
Three months later, only the building's structural shell remained.
A commercial area just south of I-30 was impacted. This strip center on Tarrant road east of 19th Street was boarded up.
This Taco Bell was closed.
Notice to customers
The McDonalds was boarded up, awaiting demolition.
This view looks north, approximately on the location of the center of the future main lanes of TX 161. The McDonalds is visible in the distance..
